original: Dīgha Nikāya 9
analyzed: dīgha nikāya
translated: Long Discourses

original: Poṭṭhapādasutta
analyzed: poṭṭhapāda sutta
translated: With Poṭṭhapāda

original: 1. Poṭṭhapādaparibbājakavatthu
analyzed: poṭṭhapāda paribbājaka vatthu
translated: The Discussion with the Wanderer Poṭṭhapāda

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ tiṁsamattehi paribbājakasatehi.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ samaya ppavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhim tisa mattehi paribbājaka satehi
translated: Now on that occasion the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda was dwelling at Sāvatthī in the park of the wanderers of other sects together with a large assembly of wanderers.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya sāvatthim piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, in the morning, the Blessed One dressed and, taking bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: Then it occurred to him:

original: “atippago kho tāva sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya carituṁ.
analyzed: atippago kho tāva sāvatthiyam piṇḍāya caritu
translated: “It is still too early to walk for alms in Sāvatthī.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo, yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham yena samayappavādakaḥ tindukācīraḥ ekasālakaḥ mallikāyaḥ ārāmaḥ yena poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājako tena upasaṅkameyyanti
translated: Let me go to the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda in the park of the wanderers of other sects.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā yena samaya ppavādakaḥ tindukācīraḥ eka sālakaḥ mallikāyaḥ ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then the Buddha went to the park of Mallika’s Mango Grove, where the wanderer Samayya was staying.🔽At that time, the wanderer Potaliya was sitting with a large assembly of wanderers who were making an uproar, loudly and noisily talking many kinds of pointless talk,🔽such as talk about kings, …

original: Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentiyā.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhim nisinnaḥ hoti unnādiniyā uccāsadda mahāsaddāya aneka vihitam tiracchāna katham kathentiyā
translated: talk about thieves, …🔽talk about killings, …🔽talk about wars, …🔽talk about food, …🔽talk about drink, …

original: Seyyathidaṁ—rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ mahāmattakathaṁ senākathaṁ bhayakathaṁ yuddhakathaṁ
analyzed: seyyathida rāja katham cora katham mahā matta katham senā katham bhaya katham yuddha katha
translated: talk about clothes, …🔽talk about beds, …🔽talk about garlands, …🔽talk about incense, …🔽talk about relatives, …

original: annakathaṁ pānakathaṁ vatthakathaṁ sayanakathaṁ mālākathaṁ gandhakathaṁ ñātikathaṁ
analyzed: anna katham pāna katham vattha katham sayana katham mālā katham gandha katham ñāti katha
translated: talk about vehicles, …🔽talk about villages, …🔽talk about towns, …🔽talk about cities, …🔽talk about states, …🔽talk about women, …

original: yānakathaṁ gāmakathaṁ nigamakathaṁ nagarakathaṁ janapadakathaṁ itthikathaṁ sūrakathaṁ
analyzed: yāna katham gāma katham nigama katham nagara katham janapada katham itthi katham sūra katha
translated: talk about heroes, …🔽talk about the present, …🔽talk about the past, …🔽talk about this world and the world beyond, …

original: visikhākathaṁ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṁ pubbapetakathaṁ nānattakathaṁ lokakkhāyikaṁ samuddakkhāyikaṁ
analyzed: visikhā katham kumbhaṭṭhāna katham pubba peta katham nānatta katham lokakkhāyikam samudda kkhāyika
translated: talk about the moon and the sun, …🔽talk about whether things exist or not, …

original: itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
analyzed: iti bhava abhava katham iti vā
translated: talk about becoming or not becoming, …

original: Addasā kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ;
analyzed: addasā kho poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam dūratas vā āgacchanta
translated: Poṭṭhapāda saw the Buddha coming in the distance

original: disvāna sakaṁ parisaṁ saṇṭhapesi:
analyzed: disvāna sakam parisam saṇṭhapesi
translated: and he addressed his assembly:

original: “appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha.
analyzed: appasaddāḥ bhonto hontu mā bhonto saddam akattha
translated: “Be quiet, sirs, and make no noise.

original: Ayaṁ samaṇo gotamo āgacchati.
analyzed: ayam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ āgacchati
translated: Here comes the ascetic Gotama.

original: Appasaddakāmo kho so āyasmā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī.
analyzed: appasadda kāmaḥ kho so āyasmat appasaddassa vaṇṇa vādī
translated: He is fond of quiet and speaks in praise of quiet.

original: Appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma appa saddam parisam viditvā upasaṅkamitabbam maññeyya ati
translated: Perhaps if he sees that our assembly is quiet he will think to join us.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
analyzed: evam vutte te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesu
translated: When he had spoken, the wanderers fell silent.

original: Atha kho bhagavā yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā yena poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājako tena upasaṅkami
translated: The Buddha went up to Poṭṭhapāda

original: Atha kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and Poṭṭhapāda said to him,

original: “etu kho, bhante, bhagavā.
analyzed: etu kho bhante bhagavā
translated: “Come, Blessed One!

original: Svāgataṁ, bhante, bhagavato.
analyzed: svāgata bhante bhagavato
translated: Welcome, Blessed One!

original: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
analyzed: cirassam kho bhante bhagavā imam pariyāyam akāsi yat idam idha āgamanāya
translated: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

original: Nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā, idaṁ āsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: nisīdatu bhante bhagavā idam āsanam paññattanti
translated: Please, sir, take a seat; this seat is ready.”

original: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane.
analyzed: nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane
translated: The Buddha sat down on the seat prepared for him

original: Poṭṭhapādopi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.🔽Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho poṭṭhapādaṁ paribbājakaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: poṭṭhapādaḥ api kho paribbājakaḥ aññataram nīcam āsanam gahetvā ekamantam nisīdi  ekamantam nisinnam kho poṭṭhapādam paribbājakam bhagavā etat avoca
translated: Poṭṭhapāda also took a low seat and sat down to one side.

original: “kāya nuttha, poṭṭhapāda, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha poṭṭhapāda etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: The Buddha said to him, “Poṭṭhapāda, what have you been sitting talking about? What conversation was unfinished when I arrived?”

original: 1.1. Abhisaññānirodhakathā
analyzed: abhisaññā nirodha kathā
translated: “A discussion about the ending of perception.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When he said this, Poṭṭhapāda said to the Buddha,

original: “tiṭṭhatesā, bhante, kathā, yāya mayaṁ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā.
analyzed: tiṭṭhate isā bhante kathā yāya mayam etarahi kathāya sannisinnā
translated: “Let’s set aside this discussion, Sir.

original: Nesā, bhante, kathā bhagavato dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya.
analyzed: na isā bhante kathā bhagavataḥ dullabhā bhavissati pacchā api savanāya
translated: It won’t be hard for you to hear it again.🔽A few days ago, a number of ascetics and brahmins of various sects and views were gathered together in the debating hall. They included:🔽the blind man’s son, the ascetic Pārāpariya; the ascetic Ambaṭṭha; the ascetic Pukkusāti; the ascetic Uttara; and the ascetic Subha.

original: Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni, nānātitthiyānaṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ kotūhalasālāya sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ abhisaññānirodhe kathā udapādi:
analyzed: purimāni bhante divasāni purimatarāni nānā titthiyānam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam kotūhala sālāya sannisinnānam sannipatitānam abhisaññā nirodhe kathā udapādi
translated: They were sitting together when this discussion came up:

original: ‘kathaṁ nu kho, bho, abhisaññānirodho hotī’ti?
analyzed: katham nu kho bho abhisaññā nirodhaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘How does the ending of perception come about?’

original: Tatrekacce evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tatra ikacce
translated: Some said this:

original: ‘ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi.
analyzed: ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjanti pi nirujjhanti pi
translated: ‘Without cause or condition a person’s perceptions arise and cease.

original: Yasmiṁ samaye uppajjanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye uppajjanti saññī tasmin samaye hoti
translated: When they arise, he is percipient.

original: Yasmiṁ samaye nirujjhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.🔽Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye nirujjhanti asaññī tasmin samaye hoti iti  itthā ike abhisaññā nirodham paññapenti
translated: When they cease, he is not percipient.’🔽This is how some describe the cessation of perception.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
analyzed: na kho pana mā ita bho evam bhavissati
translated: ‘That’s not how it is, my friend.

original: Saññā hi, bho, purisassa attā.
analyzed: saññā hi bho purisassa attā
translated: Perceptions are a person’s self.

original: Sā ca kho upetipi apetipi.🔽Yasmiṁ samaye upeti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: sā ca kho upeti pi apeti pi  yasmin samaye upeti saññī tasmin samaye hoti
translated: They come and go.🔽When they come, he is percipient.

original: Yasmiṁ samaye apeti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.🔽Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye apeti asaññī tasmin samaye hoti iti  itthā ike abhisaññā nirodham paññapenti
translated: When they go, he is not percipient.’🔽This is how some describe the cessation of perception.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: Another says:

original: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
analyzed: na kho pana mā ita bho evam bhavissati
translated: ‘That’s not how it is, my friend.

original: Santi hi, bho, samaṇabrāhmaṇā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā.🔽Te imassa purisassa saññaṁ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi.
analyzed: santi hi bho samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ mahiddhikāḥ mahā anubhāvā  te imassa purisassa saññam upakaḍḍhanti pi apakaḍḍhanti pi
translated: There are ascetics and brahmins who are powerful and mighty.🔽They can remove a person’s perceptions and then bring them back.

original: Yasmiṁ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye upakaḍḍhanti saññī tasmin samaye hoti
translated: When they remove them, he is not percipient.🔽When they bring them back, he is percipient.’

original: Yasmiṁ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye apakaḍḍhanti asaññī tasmin samaye hoti iti
translated: When they remove it, he is unconscious.’

original: Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: itthā ike abhisaññā nirodham paññapenti
translated: This is how some describe the attainment of the cessation of perception.

original: Tamañño evamāha:
analyzed: evam āha
translated: But another says:

original: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
analyzed: na kho pana mā ita bho evam bhavissati
translated: ‘That won’t do at all.

original: Santi hi, bho, devatā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā.
analyzed: santi hi bho devatāḥ mahiddhikāḥ mahā anubhāvāḥ
translated: There are deities of great psychic power & great majesty.

original: Tā imassa purisassa saññaṁ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi.🔽Yasmiṁ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: tāḥ imassa purisassa saññam upakaḍḍhanti pi apakaḍḍhanti pi  yasmin samaye upakaḍḍhanti saññī tasmin samaye hoti
translated: They can remove & add perception to a person.🔽When they add it, he is conscious.

original: Yasmiṁ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
analyzed: yasmin samaye apakaḍḍhanti asaññī tasmin samaye hoti iti
translated: When they remove it, he is unconscious.’

original: Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṁ paññapenti.
analyzed: itthā ike abhisaññā nirodham paññapenti
translated: This is how some describe the attainment of the cessation of perception.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva ārabbha sati udapādi:
analyzed: tassa bhante bhagavantayā iva ārabbha sati udapādi
translated: But, lord, the thought occurred to me:

original: ‘aho nūna bhagavā, aho nūna sugato, yo imesaṁ dhammānaṁ sukusalo’ti.
analyzed: aho nūna bhagavā aho nūna sugataḥ yaḥ imesam dhammānam su kusalaḥ ti
translated: ‘Oh, the Blessed One is skilled, the Worthy One is skilled, in that he is so skilled in these phenomena.’

original: Bhagavā, bhante, kusalo, bhagavā pakataññū abhisaññānirodhassa.
analyzed: bhagavā bhante kusalaḥ bhagavā pakata ññū abhisaññā nirodhassa
translated: The Blessed One is skilled, the Worthy One is skilled, in the attainment of the cessation of perception.

original: Kathaṁ nu kho, bhante, abhisaññānirodho hotī”ti?
analyzed: katham nu kho bhante abhisaññā nirodhaḥ hoti iti
translated: But how, lord, is there the attainment of the cessation of perception?”

original: 1.2. Sahetukasaññuppādanirodhakathā
analyzed: sa hetuka saññuppāda nirodha kathā
translated: … the discussion of the arising of perceptions with causes …

original: “Tatra, poṭṭhapāda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: tatra poṭṭhapāda ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: “Therein, Potthapada, those ascetics and Brahmins who say thus:

original: ‘ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipī’ti, āditova tesaṁ aparaddhaṁ.
analyzed: ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññāḥ uppajjanti pi nirujjhanti pi iti āditas va tesam aparaddha
translated: “Potthapada, those ascetics and brahmins who say that perceptions arise in a person without cause or condition are simply talking nonsense.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?🔽Sahetū hi, poṭṭhapāda, sappaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu  sa hetū hi poṭṭhapāda sa paccayā purisassa saññā uppajjanti pi nirujjhanti pi
translated: Why is that?🔽Perceptions arise in a person with cause and condition.

original: Sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: One perception arises in a person, another perception ceases.

original: Kā ca sikkhā”ti? Bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: kā ca sikkhā iti bhagavā avoca
translated: What is the training?”

original: “Idha, poṭṭhapāda, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ, sammāsambuddho …pe…
analyzed: idha poṭṭhapāda tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araha sammāsambuddhaḥ pe
translated: “Here, Potthapada, a Tathagata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened …

original: Evaṁ kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti …pe…
analyzed: evam kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu sīla sampannaḥ hoti pe
translated: Thus a bhikkhu is perfected in morality.

original: tassime pañcanīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassataḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he sees that these five hindrances have been abandoned within himself, joy arises in him; being joyful, his body becomes tranquil; his body tranquil, he feels pleasure; and being pleased, his mind becomes concentrated.

original: So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: saḥ vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters and dwells in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination.

original: Tassa yā purimā kāmasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā kāma saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: The perception of sensual pleasure that was previously present in him ceases.

original: Vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: At that time he has a perception that is more refined than that, a perception of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. He has a perception of what is more refined than that, a perception of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: Thus, in this way, one perception arises in him and another perception ceases in him.

original: Ayaṁ sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: ayam sikkhāti bhagavā avoca
translated: This is the training,” said the Blessed One.

original: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the stilling of thought and examination, a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the second jhāna, which has internal placidity and unification of mind and consists of rapture and pleasure born of concentration, without thought and examination.

original: Tassa yā purimā vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā viveka ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: The perception of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion that was previously present in him ceases.

original: Samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: tasmin samaye hoti samādhi ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: On that occasion there is a perception of the rapture and pleasure that are born of concentration, subtle and sublime, and he is percipient of that.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: Thus, in this way, one perception arises in him and another perception ceases in him.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.🔽“Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca🔽sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca  puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca  sampajānaḥ sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā
translated: This is the training.”

original: sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Tassa yā purimā samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati  tassa yā purimā samādhi ja pīti sukha sukhuma sacca saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: “Again, with the fading away as well of rapture, a bhikkhu abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’🔽On that occasion there is a perception of the pleasure that is in dependence on the body, subtle and sublime, and he is percipient of that.

original: Upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: upekkhā sukha sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti upekkhā sukha sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: On that occasion there is a perception of the pleasure that is in dependence on the body, subtle and sublime, and he is percipient of that.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: Thus, in this way, one perception arises in him and another perception ceases in him.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.🔽“Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva🔽somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca  puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā eva  somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamāḥ adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttha
translated: This is how training is.”

original: jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhāna, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Tassa yā purimā upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā upekkhā sukha sukhuma sacca saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: On that occasion he has a pleasant feeling.

original: Adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: adukkham asukha sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti adukkham asukha sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: On that occasion he has a pleasant feeling, and he understands: ‘At present I have a pleasant feeling.’

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: This is how training is.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca
translated: This is how training is.”

original: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, by completely surmounting the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Tassa yā purimā rūpasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā rūpa saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: Any previous perception of form ceases.

original: Ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: ākāsa anañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti ākāsa anañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: At that time he has a perception of the base of infinite space as peaceful and sublime. He is one who has a perception of the base of infinite space as peaceful and sublime.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: In this way, one perception arises in him while another perception ceases.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca
translated: This is how there is training.”

original: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Tassa yā purimā ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā ākāsa anañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: Any previous perception of the base of infinite space ceases.

original: Viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti viññāṇañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: At that time he has a perception of the base of infinite consciousness as peaceful and sublime. He is one who has a perception of the base of infinite consciousness as peaceful and sublime.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: In this way, one perception arises in him while another perception ceases.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca
translated: This is how there is training.”🔽“Again, with the complete surmounting of the base of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of nothingness.

original: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “And further, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, (perceiving) ‘There is nothing,’ a monk enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

original: Tassa yā purimā viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
analyzed: tassa yā purimā viññāṇañcāyatana sukhuma sacca saññā sā nirujjhati
translated: The subtle and refined perception of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness that was previously present for him ceases.

original: Ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana sukhuma sacca saññā tasmin samaye hoti ākiñcaññāyatana sukhuma sacca saññīyā iva tasmin samaye hoti
translated: The subtle and refined perception of the dimension of nothingness is what is present for him. He is one who perceives the subtle and refined perception of the dimension of nothingness.

original: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
analyzed: evam pi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati
translated: In this way, one perception arises in him while another perception ceases.

original: Ayampi sikkhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
analyzed: ayam pi sikkhā ati bhagavā avoca
translated: This is the training,” said the Blessed One.

original: “Yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṁ phusati.
analyzed: yatas kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu idha saka saññī hoti so tatas amutra tatas amutra anupubbena saññaggam phusati
translated: “When a monk is percipient of himself here, then from that to that, step by step, he reaches the peak of perception.

original: Tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evam hoti
translated: When he stands on the peak of perception, it occurs to him,

original: ‘cetayamānassa me pāpiyo, acetayamānassa me seyyo.
analyzed: cetayamānassa me pāpiyaḥ a cetayamānassa me seyyaḥ
translated: ‘It’s better not to will, not to generate anything.

original: Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṁ, abhisaṅkhareyyaṁ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṁ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṁ;
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana ceteyya abhisaṅkhareyya imāḥ ca me saññāḥ nirujjheyyu aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyu
translated: If I were to intend and plan, these perceptions of mine would cease, and gross perceptions would arise.

original: yannūnāhaṁ na ceva ceteyyaṁ na ca abhisaṅkhareyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham na ca iva ceteyyam na ca abhisaṅkhareyyanti
translated: Why don’t I neither intend nor plan?’

original: So na ceva ceteti, na ca abhisaṅkharoti.
analyzed: saḥ na ca iva cetā iti na ca abhisaṅkharoti
translated: So he neither intends nor plans.

original: Tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti.
analyzed: tassa a cetayataḥ an abhisaṅkharotaḥ tāḥ ca iva saññāḥ nirujjhanti aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti
translated: As he neither intends nor plans, those perceptions cease, and other, grosser perceptions do not arise.

original: So nirodhaṁ phusati.
analyzed: saḥ nirodham phusati
translated: He contacts cessation.

original: Evaṁ kho, poṭṭhapāda, anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpatti hoti.
analyzed: evam kho poṭṭhapāda anupubba abhisaññā nirodha sampajāna samāpatti hoti
translated: This is how there is the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling.

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi poṭṭhapāda
translated: What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda?

original: api nu te ito pubbe evarūpā anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpatti sutapubbā”ti?
analyzed: api nu te itas pubbe evarūpā anupubba abhisaññā nirodha sampajāna samāpatti suta pubbā ti
translated: Have you ever heard of such a attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling before?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, lord.

original: Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavato bhāsitaṁ ājānāmi:
analyzed: evam kho aha bhante bhagavataḥ bhāsitam ājānāmi
translated: I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One to be like this.

original: ‘yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṁ phusati,
analyzed: yatas kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu idha saka saññī hoti so tatas amutra tatas amutra anupubbena saññaggam phusati
translated: ‘When a monk is percipient of this thus, then due to the cessation of his perceptions, he attains the cessation of identification.

original: tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evam hoti
translated: When he is established in that perception, he thinks:

original: “cetayamānassa me pāpiyo, acetayamānassa me seyyo.
analyzed: cetayamānassa me pāpiyaḥ a cetayamānassa me seyyaḥ
translated: ‘It’s worse when I intend than when I don’t intend.

original: Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṁ abhisaṅkhareyyaṁ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṁ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṁ;
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana ceteyyam abhisaṅkhareyya imāḥ ca me saññāḥ nirujjheyyu aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyu
translated: If I were to intend and plan, these perceptions of mine would cease, and gross perceptions would arise.

original: yannūnāhaṁ na ceva ceteyyaṁ, na ca abhisaṅkhareyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham na ca iva ceteyya na ca abhisaṅkhareyyanti
translated: Why don’t I neither intend nor plan?’

original: So na ceva ceteti, na cābhisaṅkharoti, tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti.
analyzed: so na ca iva ceteti na ca abhisaṅkharoti tassa a cetayataḥ an abhisaṅkharotaḥ tāḥ ca iva saññāḥ nirujjhanti aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti
translated: So he neither intends nor plans. As he doesn’t intend or plan, those perceptions cease, and other, even grosser perceptions don’t arise.

original: So nirodhaṁ phusati.
analyzed: saḥ nirodham phusati
translated: He contacts cessation.

original: Evaṁ kho, poṭṭhapāda, anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpatti hotī’”ti.
analyzed: evam kho poṭṭhapāda anupubba abhisaññā nirodha sampajāna samāpatti hoti iti
translated: This is how there is the realization of the stilling of all activities, the relinquishment of all acquisitions, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, extinguishment.”

original: “Evaṁ, poṭṭhapādā”ti.
analyzed: eva poṭṭhapādā ati
translated: “Yes, Poṭṭhapāda.”

original: “Ekaññeva nu kho, bhante, bhagavā saññaggaṁ paññapeti, udāhu puthūpi saññagge paññapetī”ti?
analyzed: ekaññā iva nu kho bhante bhagavā saññaggam paññapeti udāhu puthu upi saññagge paññapeti iti
translated: “Does the Buddha describe only one kind of summit of perception, or many kinds of summits of perception?”

original: “Ekampi kho ahaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, saññaggaṁ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī”ti.
analyzed: ekam api kho aha poṭṭhapāda saññaggam paññapemi puthu upi saññagge paññapemi iti
translated: “Poṭṭhapāda, I describe one kind of summit of perception, and I describe many kinds of summits of perception.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bhante, bhagavā ekampi saññaggaṁ paññapeti, puthūpi saññagge paññapetī”ti?
analyzed: yathā katham pana bhante bhagavā ekam pi saññaggam paññapeti puthu upi saññagge paññapeti iti
translated: “But how does the Buddha describe the different kinds of higher wisdom?”

original: “Yathā yathā kho, poṭṭhapāda, nirodhaṁ phusati tathā tathāhaṁ saññaggaṁ paññapemi.
analyzed: yathā yathā kho poṭṭhapāda nirodham phusati tathā tathā aham saññaggam paññapemi
translated: “I describe the different kinds of higher wisdom according to the way one experiences cessation.

original: Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, ekampi saññaggaṁ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho aha poṭṭhapāda ekam api saññaggam paññapemi puthu upi saññagge paññapemi iti
translated: In this way I describe the different kinds of higher wisdom, both individually and collectively.”

original: “Saññā nu kho, bhante, paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, udāhu ñāṇaṁ paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā saññā, udāhu saññā ca ñāṇañca apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjantī”ti?
analyzed: saññā nu kho bhante paṭhamam uppajjati pacchā ñāṇe udāhu ñāṇam paṭhamam uppajjati pacchā saññā udāhu saññā ca ñāṇañca apubbam acarimam uppajjanti iti
translated: “But, Sir, does perception arise first, and knowledge after, or does knowledge arise first, and perception after, or do they arise simultaneously?”

original: “Saññā kho, poṭṭhapāda, paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hoti.
analyzed: saññā kho poṭṭhapāda paṭhamam uppajjati pacchā ñāṇa saññā uppādā ca pana ñāṇa uppādo hoti
translated: “Perception arises first, knowledge after. The arising of knowledge is dependent on the arising of perception.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: One understands thus:

original: ‘idappaccayā kira me ñāṇaṁ udapādī’ti.
analyzed: idappaccayā kira me ñāṇam udapādi iti
translated: ‘My knowledge has arisen with the arising of perception.’

original: Iminā kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ—
analyzed: iminā kho eta poṭṭhapāda pariyāyena veditabba
translated: This is how it should be understood that

original: yathā saññā paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hotī”ti.
analyzed: yathā saññā paṭhamam uppajjati pacchā ñāṇa saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hoti iti
translated: how perception arises first, and then knowledge, and the arising of perception is the arising of knowledge.”

original: 1.3. Saññāattakathā
analyzed: saññā atta kathā
translated: … Discussion of perception

original: “Saññā nu kho, bhante, purisassa attā, udāhu aññā saññā añño attā”ti?
analyzed: saññā nu kho bhante purisassa attā udāhu aññā saññā aññaḥ attā ati
translated: “Is perception a person’s self, or is perception one thing and self another?”

original: “Kaṁ pana tvaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, attānaṁ paccesī”ti?
analyzed: kam pana tva poṭṭhapāda attānam paccesi iti
translated: “But, Poṭṭhapāda, what do you think: what is your self like?”

original: “Oḷārikaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, attānaṁ paccemi rūpiṁ cātumahābhūtikaṁ kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhan”ti.
analyzed: oḷārikam kho aha bhante attānam paccemi rūpim cātumahābhūtikam kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkhanti
translated: “Sir, I hold that my self is material, made up of the four primary elements, and fed by material food.”

original: “Oḷāriko ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho. Evaṁ santaṁ kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
analyzed: oḷārikaḥ ca hi te poṭṭhapāda attā abhavissa rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkho evam santam kho te poṭṭhapāda aññā ava saññā bhavissati aññaḥ attā
translated: “If your self were material, made up of the four primary elements, and fed by material food, then your perception would be one thing and your self another.

original: Tadamināpetaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
analyzed: poṭṭhapāda pariyāyena veditabbam yathā aññā ava saññā bhavissati aññaḥ attā
translated: In this way it can be known how perception is one thing and self another.

original: Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, oḷāriko attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhatā iva sāya poṭṭhapāda oḷārikaḥ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkho atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti
translated: “Even though this gross physical body remains, still his perceptions will be different, and his mind will be different.

original: Iminā kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā”ti.
analyzed: iminā kho eta poṭṭhapāda pariyāyena veditabbam yathā aññā ava saññā bhavissati aññaḥ attā iti
translated: It’s in this way that you should understand how there can be a difference in perception and mind.”

translated: you will exist in the future, you will not not exist;

original: atthi tvaṁ etarahi, na tvaṁ natthī’ti.
analyzed: atthi tvam etarahi na tvam natthi iti
translated: you exist at present, you do not not exist.’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyaṁ:
analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ aha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: If I were asked this, venerable sir, I would answer thus:

original: ‘ahosāhaṁ atītamaddhānaṁ, nāhaṁ na ahosiṁ;
analyzed: ahosāham atītam addhāna na aham na ahosi
translated: ‘I existed in the past, I did not not exist;

original: bhavissāmahaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, nāhaṁ na bhavissāmi;
analyzed: bhavissāmaham anāgatam addhāna na aham na bhavissāmi
translated: I will exist in the future, I will not not exist;

original: atthāhaṁ etarahi, nāhaṁ natthī’ti.
analyzed: attha aham etarahi na aham natthi iti
translated: I exist at present, I do not not exist.’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyan”ti.
analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ aha bhante evam byākareyyanti
translated: If I were asked this, venerable sir, I would answer thus.”

original: “Sace pana taṁ, citta, evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:
analyzed: sace pana evam puccheyyu
translated: “But if you were asked thus, Citta:

original: ‘yo te ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno?🔽Yo te bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno?
analyzed: yaḥ te ahosi atītaḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ anāgataḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno  yaḥ te bhavissati anāgataḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno
translated: ‘The self you had in the past: is that the same as your present self, or is it one thing in the past and another now?🔽The self you will have in the future: is that the same as your present self, or is it one thing in the future and another now?

original: Yo te etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ te etarahi paccuppannaḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ anāgataḥ ti
translated: Your present self: is that the same as your self in the past and the future, or is it one thing in the past and the future, and another now?’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭho tvaṁ, citta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?
analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ tva citta kinti byākareyyāsi iti
translated: What would you say to that, Cittan?”

original: “Sace pana maṁ, bhante, evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:🔽‘yo te ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno.🔽Yo te bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno.
analyzed: sace pana ma bhante evam puccheyyu  yaḥ te ahosi atītaḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ anāgataḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno  yaḥ te bhavissati anāgataḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno
translated: “Sir, if I’m asked this,🔽‘The self you had in the past: is that the same as your present self, or is it one thing in the past and another now?🔽The self you will have in the future: is that the same as your present self, or is it one thing in the future and another now?

original: Yo te etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ te etarahi paccuppannaḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva te atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ anāgataḥ ti
translated: Your present self: is that the same as your self in the past and the future, or is it one thing in the past and the future, and another now?’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyaṁ:
analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ aha bhante evam byākareyya
translated: If asked this, I would answer in this way:

original: ‘yo me ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho tasmiṁ samaye sacco ahosi, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno.🔽Yo me bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho tasmiṁ samaye sacco bhavissati, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno.
analyzed: yaḥ me ahosi atītaḥ atta paṭilābho so uva me atta paṭilābho tasmin samaye saccaḥ ahosi moghaḥ anāgataḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno  yaḥ me bhavissati anāgataḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva me atta paṭilābhaḥ tasmin samaye saccaḥ bhavissati moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ paccuppanno
translated: ‘The self I had in the past was true, while the future and present selves were false.🔽The self I will have in the future will be true, while the past and present selves are false.

original: Yo me etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ me etarahi paccuppannaḥ atta paṭilābho saḥ uva me atta paṭilābhaḥ saccaḥ moghaḥ atītaḥ moghaḥ anāgataḥ ti
translated: The self I have in the present is true, while the past and future selves are false.’

original: Evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyan”ti.
analyzed: evam puṭṭhaḥ aha bhante evam byākareyyanti
translated: If asked this, I would answer in this way.”🔽“So too, when there is a bodily self, the mind-made and formless selves are not evident.

original: “Evameva kho, citta, yasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na arūpo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati.🔽Oḷāriko attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: evam eva kho citta yasmin samaye oḷārikaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ hoti na iva tasmin samaye manaḥ mayaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati na arūpaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati 🔽oḷārikaḥ tasmin samaye saṅkham gacchati
translated: Only the bodily self is evident.

original: Yasmiṁ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
analyzed: yasmi citta samaye manaḥ mayaḥ hoti pe
translated: On an occasion, Citta, when there is a mind-made attainment of a self …

original: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: yasmi citta samaye arūpaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ hoti na iva tasmin samaye oḷārikaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati na manaḥ mayaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati
translated: On the occasion when there is a mind-made attainment of self, on that occasion there is no attainment of self that is gross, there is no attainment of self that is mind-made;

original: arūpo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: arūpaḥ tasmin samaye saṅkham gacchati
translated: on that occasion there is only an attainment of self that is formless.

original: Seyyathāpi, citta, gavā khīraṁ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṁ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo.
analyzed: seyyathā api citta gavā khīra khīramhā dadhi dadhimhā navanīta navanītamhā sappi sappimhā sappi maṇḍaḥ
translated: “Just as from milk come curd, butter, ghee, and cream-of-ghee,

original: Yasmiṁ samaye khīraṁ hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye dadhīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappimaṇḍoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: yasmin samaye khīram hoti na iva tasmin samaye dadhi iti saṅkham gacchati na navanītam iti saṅkham gacchati na sappī iti saṅkham gacchati na sappimaṇḍā uti saṅkham gacchati
translated: on the occasion when there is milk, there is no curd, butter, ghee, or cream-of-ghee;

original: khīrantveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.🔽Yasmiṁ samaye dadhi hoti …pe…🔽navanītaṁ hoti …
analyzed: tasmin samaye saṅkham gacchati  yasmin samaye dadhi hoti  navanītam ha iti
translated: on that occasion there is only milk.🔽On the occasion when there is curd …🔽butter …

original: sappi hoti …
analyzed: sappi hoti
translated: ghee …

original: sappimaṇḍo hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye khīranti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na dadhīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: sappi maṇḍaḥ hoti na iva tasmin samaye khīranti saṅkham gacchati na dadhi iti saṅkham gacchati na navanītanti saṅkham gacchati na sappi iti saṅkham gacchati
translated: it is no longer called milk, curd, fresh butter, or ghee,

original: sappimaṇḍotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: sappimaṇḍā ūtvā iva tasmin samaye saṅkham gacchati
translated: but simply ‘ghee’.

original: Evameva kho, citta, yasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
analyzed: evam eva khalu citta yasmin samaye oḷārikaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ hoti pe
translated: In the same way, Citta, on an occasion when there is a bodily pleasure…

original: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
analyzed: yasmi citta samaye manaḥ mayaḥ hoti pe
translated: on an occasion when there is a mental pleasure…

original: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: yasmi citta samaye arūpaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ hoti na iva tasmin samaye oḷārikaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati na manaḥ mayaḥ atta paṭilābhaḥ uti saṅkham gacchati
translated: on an occasion when there is a non-percipient, non-cognizant embodiment, it is no longer called a bodily pleasure, a mental pleasure, or a non-percipient, non-cognizant embodiment,

original: arūpo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: arūpaḥ tasmin samaye saṅkham gacchati
translated: but simply ‘a non-percipient, non-cognizant embodiment’.

original: Imā kho, citta, lokasamaññā lokaniruttiyo lokavohārā lokapaññattiyo, yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasan”ti.
analyzed: imāḥ kho citta loka samaññāḥ loka niruttiyaḥ loka vohārāḥ loka paññattiyaḥ yāhi tathāgataḥ voharati a parāmasanti
translated: These are the worldly conventions, designations in the world, worldly expressions and designations, by which the Tathāgata expresses himself without grasping at them.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte poṭṭhapādaḥ paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Blessed One:

original: “abhikkantaṁ, bhante, abhikkantaṁ, bhante.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: abhikkanta bhante abhikkanta bhante  sā iyyathā api bhante nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent!

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: in the same way has Master Gotama—through many lines of reasoning—made the Dhamma clear.

original: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: esā aha bhante bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go to Master Gotama for refuge, to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha of monks.

original: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
analyzed: upāsakam mam bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇa upetam saraṇam gatanti
translated: May Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge, from this day forward, for life.”

original: 2.3. Cittahatthisāriputtaupasampadā
analyzed: citta hatthi sāriputta upasampadā
translated: .. The Acceptance of Citta Hatthisāriputta

original: Citto pana hatthisāriputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: cittaḥ pana hatthi sāriputtaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then Citta Hatthisāriputta said to the Blessed One:

original: “abhikkantaṁ, bhante, abhikkantaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: abhikkanta bhante abhikkanta bhante
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent!

original: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: sā iyyathā api bhante nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: just as one with eyes might hold up a light in the darkness, saying, ‘Those with eyes will see forms,’

original: evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: so too, the Blessed One has revealed the Dhamma in many ways.

original: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: esā aha bhante bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go for refuge to the Blessed One, to the Dhamma, & to the Saṅgha of monks.

original: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti
translated: May I receive the going forth in the Blessed One’s presence? May I receive the full admission.”

original: Alattha kho citto hatthisāriputto bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.🔽Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī🔽pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ
analyzed: alattha kho cittaḥ hatthi sāriputtaḥ bhagavato santike pabbajja alattha upasampada  acira upasampannaḥ kho pana āyasmā cittaḥ hatthi sāriputto ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ appamattaḥ ātāpī  pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ na kula puttā sammad eva agārasma anagāriya
translated: The brahman student Citta received the going forth in the Blessed One’s presence, he received the full admission.

original: pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
analyzed: pabbajanti tad anuttara brahmacariya pariyosānam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi
translated: Not long after his full admission, staying by himself, withdrawn, heedful, ardent, & resolute, the Ven. Citta Hatthisariputta, in no long time, reached & remained in the supreme goal of the holy life, for which clansmen rightly go forth from home into homelessness, knowing & realizing it for himself in the here & now.🔽He directly knew: “Birth is ended, the holy life fulfilled, the task done. There is nothing further for the sake of this world.”

original: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthAttāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
analyzed: vusitam brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati
translated: “Birth is ended, the spiritual life fulfilled, the job done. There is nothing further for this world.”

original: Aññataro kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahataṁ ahosīti.
analyzed: aññataraḥ kho pana āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahatam ahosi iti
translated: And Venerable Citta Hatthisariputta became another one of the perfected.

original: Poṭṭhapādasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: poṭṭhapāda suttam niṭṭhitam navama
translated: The ninth section for recitation on Poṭṭhapāda is finished.
